docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Reading your May 15 editorial on the two-pronged assault of Republican budget cuts on teaching hospitals, I agree with the first twothirds, but disagree with the rest. When you turn to support managed care plans, I believe you overlook their influence, as a third major assault on all physicians, not just teaching hospitals.

headline.main: Managed Care's Killing the Practice of Medicine

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time since the golden 60's, the goal of a balanced budget suddenly seems within reach. The idea is hugely popular. The new Republican majority apparently has the clout to make it happen. And now the House and Senate Republicans have produced their versions of a balanced budget, complete with timetables and dollar targets. Many of the particulars will change as Congress hammers out a compromise. And no one can know whether the moment's political resolve will buckle -- it's happened before -- or whether the plan will indeed whittle the deficit from $200 billion to zero in a mere seven years. But whatever comes of the negotiations is bound to follow the current formula of stiff restraints on health care spending, a freeze on defense and deep cuts in Government programs.

headline.main: The Nation: Balancing Ax; Doing Well in a Deficit-Free America. Or Not So Well.

docs.lead_paragraph: HEAD starts often bring handsome profits. That's the essential strategy of the new-issues market, and it is being deftly played out by a dental care company that will go public later this month. The company is APPS Dental, based in Atlanta. The idea behind the enterprise -- managed care -- is hardly novel. "It's the strategy that's in vogue," said Mark Basham, an analyst with Standard & Poor's. But APPS is extending managed care to a field that is fairly wide open: the $40 billion dental market.

headline.main: A Fast Track In Managed Dental Care

docs.lead_paragraph: LOREN KALISH was 24 and frightened. Burson-Marsteller, the public relations giant on Park Avenue South where she works as an associate, had just announced that all employees had to choose a health-maintenance organization. She knew H.M.O.'s usually require patients to see only doctors in their networks and insist on approving any visit to a specialist. But a "wonderful doctor" at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center had seen her through the ordeal of several irregular Pap smear readings, and she dreaded being treated by anyone else.

headline.main: The Brochures Pile Up. The Decision Presses. The Question: To Join or Not to Join?

docs.lead_paragraph: To Mike Brown, who runs a tiny county health care center about an hour's drive from here, the $250 billion or so in Medicare savings that Congressional Republicans want to achieve over the next seven years is more than an abstract figure in a Washington budget battle. Like many rural hospitals, his center, Saunders County Health Services, ministers to a population that is largely elderly and exceedingly dependent on Medicare. The health insurance program for the elderly accounts for about 40 percent of hospital revenue nationally but for more than 80 percent of the hospital revenue at the Saunders County center.

headline.main: Medicare Talk Brings Anxiety To Heartland

docs.lead_paragraph: Stagehands Go Off Broadway The stagehands union has quietly moved to try to unionize Off Broadway theaters. The union, Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, has asked the National Labor Relations Board to recognize it as the bargaining agent for employees at six important Off Broadway theaters: the Union Square, the Orpheum, the Minetta Lane, the Cherry Lane, and the upstairs and downstairs Westside Arts Theaters. The first four are owned or managed by Minetta Lane Management, run by Alan Schuster and Mitchell Maxwell; the last two by Peter Askin. Employees of Ben Sprecher, another leading Off Broadway landlord, were apparently not approached.

docs.lead_paragraph: Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said today that he had reluctantly concluded that Republicans would have to "go it alone" in cutting projected spending on Medicare because President Clinton and Democrats in Congress had refused to join the effort. But Mr. Barbour said Republicans could reap political dividends because they would receive most of the credit for saving Medicare from bankruptcy.

headline.main: G.O.P. May 'Go It Alone' On Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: "Make no mistake about it, this bill is a historic watershed," said Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. "If this bill does not work, or if Congress and the President attempt to frustrate it, we will lose our last significant opportunity to deal with the deficit." Those sentiments were expressed repeatedly today as the House of Representatives approved a resolution that is supposed to lead to a balanced budget by 2002 and the Senate began debate on a companion measure.

docs.lead_paragraph: A medical laboratory that performs 70 million clinical tests a year agreed yesterday to pay $8.6 million to the Federal Government to settle allegations that it submitted false claims to Medicare and other government programs for tests that were never performed. MetPath Inc. -- which is in the process of changing its name to Corning Clinical Laboratories Inc. -- does not acknowledge any wrongdoing in the settlement, saying a billing error was to blame for the mistakes.
